Will_Oldham:
{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and actor (born 1970)}} {{redirect|Palace Music|the racehorse|Palace Music (horse)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}} {{Use American English|date=July 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Will Oldham | image = Bonnie-Prince-Billy-060609 (614bw) (3606166772).jpg | caption = Oldham in 2009 | landscape = yes | image_size = | birth_name = | alias = Palace Brothers
Palace Music
Palace Songs
Bonnie "Prince" Billy | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1970|01|15}} | birth_place = [[Louisville, Kentucky]], U.S. | origin = | instrument = | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country rock]]{{cite web |url=https://www.clevescene.com/music/white-lies-bishop-allen-and-others-get-graded-1534927 |title=White Lies, Bishop Allen And Others Get Graded |last=Gribbins |first=Keith |date=March 18, 2009 |publisher=CleveScene |access-date=2022-04-14}} * [[freak folk]]{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2005/10/bjork-the-music-from-drawing-restraint-9.html |title=Björk: Björk – The music from Drawing Restraint 9 |website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |date=June 30, 2008 |access-date=August 8, 2016}} * [[gothic country]] * [[Lo-fi music|lo-fi]] * [[indie folk]] * [[alternative country]] }} | occupation = | years_active = 1993–present | label = {{flatlist| *[[Drag City (record label)|Drag City]] *[[Domino Recording Company|Domino]] *Spunk }} | associated_acts = [[Faun Fables|Dawn McCarthy]], [[Boxhead Ensemble]], [[Emmett Kelly (musician)|The Cairo Gang]], [[Mekons]], [[Matt Sweeney]], [[Mick Turner]], [[Tortoise (band)|Tortoise]], [[Trembling Bells]], [[Harem Scarem]], The Picket Line, [[Alex Neilson]], [[Björk]], [[Slint]], [[Silver Jews]], [[Joan Shelley]], [[Bill Callahan (musician)|Bill Callahan]] | website = {{URL|bonnieprincebilly.com}} }} '''Joseph Will Oldham''' (born January 15, 1970) is an American singer-songwriter and actor. From 1993 to 1997, he performed and recorded in collaboration with dozens of other musicians under variations of '''Palace''' (Palace, Palace Brothers, Palace Songs, and Palace Music).{{Cite web |title=Will Oldham (Bonnie Prince Billy) |url=https://www.wypr.org/podcast/essential-tremors/2022-04-28/will-oldham-bonnie-prince-billy |access-date=2022-06-14 |website=WYPR |language=en}} After briefly publishing music under his own name, in 1998 he adopted '''Bonnie''' "'''Prince'''" '''Billy''' as the name for most of his work. ==Early life and education== Oldham was born on January 15, 1970, in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].Alan Licht (Ed.) (2012), ''Will Oldham on Bonnie "Prince" Billy''. Faber and Faber Ltd., London, pp. viii. {{ISBN|978-0-571-25814-7}}. His mother, Joanne Lei Will Tafel Oldham, was a teacher and artist.{{Cite web|title=Joanne Oldham (1942 - 2020) - Obituary|url=https://www.legacy.com/amp/obituaries/louisville/195122836|access-date=2020-10-23|website=legacy.com}} His father, Joseph Collins Oldham, was an attorney and photographer.{{Cite web|title=Joseph Oldham - Obituary|url=https://www.legacy.com/amp/obituaries/louisville/19382161|access-date=2020-10-23|website=legacy.com}} Oldham graduated from the [[J. Graham Brown School]] in 1988. He attended [[Brown University]] sporadically while pursuing a career as an actor, and living between [[Brooklyn]], [[Los Angeles]], and [[Bloomington, Indiana]].{{cite web | publisher = [Indiana Public Media] | date = February 17, 2016 | author=Adam Schwartz | title = Bonnie "Prince" Billy Tells of His Royal Roots | url=https://indianapublicmedia.org/arts/bonnie-prince-billy-tells-of-his-royal-roots.php | access-date = July 14, 2021 }} He began making music during this time, initially as a project for his professor [[Jeff Todd Titon]], an ethnomusicologist at Brown University.{{cite web | publisher = [[The Wire (magazine)|The Wire]] | date = March 14, 2013 | author=Derek Walmsley | title = Exclusive Bonnie 'Prince' Billy Interview | url=http://www.thewire.co.uk/in-writing/interviews/exclusive-bonnie_prince_billy-interview | access-date = January 25, 2016 }} == Career == [[File:Will Oldham 2017.jpg|thumb|Oldham in 2017]] Oldham is known for his "[[DIY ethic|do-it-yourself]] punk aesthetic and blunt honesty",{{cite web | publisher = Chico News & Review | date = March 28, 2002 | author=Baldwin, C. | title = The Wanderer | url=http://www.newsreview.com/chico/Content?oid=8724 | access-date = May 8, 2007 }} and his music has been likened to [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[American folk music|folk]], [[Traditional music|roots]], [[country music|country]], [[punk music|punk]], and [[indie rock]]. He has been called an "[[Appalachia]]n [[post-punk]] [[solipsist]]", with a voice that has been described as "a fragile sort-of warble frittering around haunted melodies in the American folk or country tradition." Oldham first performed and recorded under various permutations of the Palace name, including Palace Brothers, Palace Songs, Palace Music, and simply Palace. Regarding the name changes during this period (1993–1997), Oldham said: {{cquote|I guess the idea is that when you have a name of a group or an artist, then you expect that the next record, if it has the same name, should be the same group of people playing on it. And I just thought we were making a different kind of record each time, with different people, and different themes, and different sounds. So I thought it was important to call it something different so that people would be aware of the differences.}} Will stated in a 1995 interview with [[KCRW]] that the name Palace Flophouse was inspired by reading [[John Steinbeck]]'s ''[[Cannery Row (novel)|Cannery Row]]''. Beginning in 1998, Oldham has primarily used the moniker Bonnie 'Prince' Billy, which draws inspiration from several sources: {{cquote|[T]he name has so many different references that it could almost have a life of its own. [[Bonnie Prince Charlie]] has such a beautiful ring to it, and I was very conscious of appropriating that mellifluous sound. And I was also thinking about the name [[Nat King Cole]]. But it wasn't until later, and this may have been subconscious, that I remembered that [[Billy the Kid]] was William Bonney or Billy Bonney.{{cite web | work = [[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Phoenix]] | date = January 20, 2003 | author = Ashare, Matt | title = Mystery Man: Palace Brother Will Oldham becomes Bonnie 'Prince' Billy | url = http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/music/top/documents/02671921.htm | access-date = May 9, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081202151640/http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/music/top/documents/02671921.htm | archive-date = December 2, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}}} He has explained that "the primary purpose of the pseudonym is to allow both the audience and the performer to have a relationship with the performer that is valid and unbreakable."{{cite web | publisher = Foggy Notion |date=April 2003 | title = Bonnie 'Prince' Billy | url=http://www.dragcity.com/press/pimages/pressclips/dc233fn_art.pdf | access-date = May 8, 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070710021351/http://www.dragcity.com/press/pimages/pressclips/dc233fn_art.pdf |archive-date = July 10, 2007}} ===Critical reception=== Some of his albums, such as ''[[There Is No-One What Will Take Care of You]]'' (1993),{{cite book | last = Irvin | first = Jim |author2=Colin McLear | title = The Mojo Collection: The Ultimate Music Companion | publisher = Canongate | year = 2003|edition=3rd | page = [https://archive.org/details/mojocollectiongr00jimi/page/585 585] | isbn = 1-84195-438-1 | title-link = The Mojo Collection }} ''[[Viva Last Blues]]'' (1995),{{cite web | publisher = Pitchfork Media | date = November 17, 2003 | author = LeMay, Matt | title = The Top 100 Albums of the 1990s | url = http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/36737-staff-list-top-100-albums-of-the-1990s/page_5 | access-date = May 8, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070506045834/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/36737-staff-list-top-100-albums-of-the-1990s/page_5 | archive-date = May 6, 2007 | df = mdy-all }} and ''[[I See a Darkness]]'' (1999),{{cite book | last = Irvin | first = Jim | author2 = Colin McLear | title = The Mojo Collection: The Ultimate Music Companion | publisher = Canongate | year = 2003 | edition = 3rd | page = [https://archive.org/details/mojocollectiongr00jimi/page/651 651] | isbn = 1-84195-438-1 | url-access = registration | url = https://archive.org/details/mojocollectiongr00jimi/page/651 }}{{cite web | publisher = Pitchfork Media | date = November 17, 2003 | author=Bowers, William | title = The Top 100 Albums of the 1990s | url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/feature/36737-staff-list-top-100-albums-of-the-1990s/page_10 | access-date = May 8, 2007 }}{{cite book | last = Dimery | first = Robert | title = 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die | publisher = Universe | year = 2006 | page = [https://archive.org/details/albumsyoumusthea00dime/page/n429 854] | isbn = 0-7893-1371-5 | title-link = 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die }} have appeared on greatest albums lists. [[Johnny Cash]] recorded a version of "I See a Darkness" on his [[American Recordings (US)|American Recordings]] disc ''[[American III: Solitary Man]]'' (2000). Oldham provided backing vocals. Spanish singer [[Rosalía]] also recorded a version of "I See a Darkness" for her debut album ''[[Los Ángeles (album)|Los Ángeles]]''. [[Marianne Faithfull]] included Oldham's "A King at Night" on her 2003 ''Kissin Time'' tour. [[Steve Adey]] also covered "I See a Darkness" on his 2006 LP ''[[All Things Real]]''. [[Mark Kozelek]] recorded a version of Oldham's "New Partner" on his 2008 disc, ''[[The Finally LP]]''. [[Katatonia]] covered "Oh How I Enjoy the Light" on their 2001 EP ''[[Tonight's Music]]'', and their song "Don't Tell a Soul" is about and contains an interpolation of the Palace Brothers song "You Will Miss Me When I Burn". In 2009 [[Mark Lanegan]] and [[Soulsavers]] recorded a cover version of "You Will Miss Me When I Burn". The release is a split single, backed with the Lanegan-penned "Sunrise" featuring vocals by Oldham. In 2011, [[Deer Tick (band)|Deer Tick]]'s cover of Oldham's song "Death to Everyone" appeared in an episode of ''[[Hell on Wheels (TV series)|Hell On Wheels]]''. [[Cadaverous Condition]] covered "Black" on their ''To the Night Sky'' album (2006). ===Acting=== ====Film and television==== Oldham's first film acting role was as the teen preacher in [[John Sayles]]'s film ''[[Matewan]]'' (1987), a dramatization of the life of Appalachian mining community in the 1920s and the [[Battle of Matewan]]. Following this, he moved to Hollywood to pursue a career as an actor.{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Randall|date=June 3, 2009|title=Will Oldham's Trouble with Hollywood|publisher=Dallas Observer|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2009-06-04/music/will-oldham-s-trouble-with-hollywood/|access-date=January 16, 2010}} He played the role of Chip McClure (father of [[Jessica McClure|Baby Jessica]]) in ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]'' (1989), and the role of Miles in the film ''[[Thousand Pieces of Gold (film)|Thousand Pieces of Gold]]'' (1991). Oldham also played minor roles in ''[[Julien Donkey-Boy]]'' (1999), ''[[Junebug (film)|Junebug]]'' (2005), and ''[[The Guatemalan Handshake]]'' (2006). In 2004, Oldham appeared as himself in the short documentary film ''Tripping With Caveh'', wherein he took [[psilocybin mushrooms]] with autobiographical filmmaker [[Caveh Zahedi]].''[[New York Times]]'' article: "[https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/30/magazine/caveh-zahedi-documentary-film.html A Filmmaker Bared His Soul. It Ruined His Life].""[https://vimeo.com/65958992 Tripping With Caveh] on Caveh Zahedi's [[Vimeo]] page. The project was intended as the pilot episode of a reality/documentary series, with the concept being that Zahedi would take [[psychedelic drug|psychedelics]] in the company of a different celebrity in each episode. The project was never picked up by a television network, but the short with Oldham finally saw official release in the 2015 retrospective box set ''Digging My Own Grave: The Films of Caveh Zahedi''.Factory Twenty Five: "[https://www.factorytwentyfive.com/shop/digging-my-own-grave Digging My Own Grave]." Oldham played a lead role as Kurt in [[Kelly Reichardt]]'s film ''[[Old Joy (film)|Old Joy]]'' (2006), and had a brief role in the director's next film ''[[Wendy and Lucy]]'' (2008). Oldham played Pastor Pigmeat in the "Horse Apples" episode of the second season of the [[MTV]] [[children's show]] parody ''[[Wonder Showzen]]'' and appeared in an episode of Chatman and Lee's subsequent television show, ''[[Xavier: Renegade Angel]]'' as a Reverend.{{Citation |last1=Bertoldo |first1=Marco |title=Signs from Godrilla |date=2008-01-06 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1171491/?ref_=ttep_ep9 |series=Xavier: Renegade Angel |access-date=2023-03-02 |last2=Chatman |first2=Vernon |last3=Lee |first3=John}} In 2007, he starred alongside [[Zach Galifianakis]] in a music video for [[Kanye West]]'s "[[Can't Tell Me Nothing]]".[https://www.wired.com/underwire/2007/07/the-kanye-westw/ The Kanye West/Will Oldham/Zach Galifianakis Collabo You Never Saw Coming]. [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]], July 25, 2007. Retrieved on August 23, 2012. Also in 2010, Oldham appeared in ''[[Jackass 3D]]'' as a gorilla trainer. As part of an agreement to play that role, he wrote a theme song, in the style of a Saturday-morning cartoon show, for filmmaker [[Lance Bangs]].[http://www.buzzgrinder.com/2011/will-oldham-new-album-jackass-3d/ Will Oldham Discusses Jackass 3D, Working on 'Blueprints' for New Album] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312102807/http://www.buzzgrinder.com/2011/will-oldham-new-album-jackass-3d/ |date=March 12, 2011 }}. Buzzgrinder.com (March 9, 2011). Retrieved on May 4, 2012. In 2011, Oldham played a father telling a bedtime story to his son in [[David Lowery (director)|David Lowery's]] short film ''Pioneer''.{{Cite web |last=Salovaara |first=Sarah |date=2015-04-22 |title=Watch: David Lowery's Pioneer {{!}} Filmmaker Magazine |url=https://filmmakermagazine.com/93910-watch-david-lowerys-pioneer/ |access-date=2023-10-26 |website=Filmmaker Magazine {{!}} Publication with a focus on independent film, offering articles, links, and resources. |language=en-US}} In 2017, he appeared as "Prognosticator" in the feature film ''[[A Ghost Story]]'', also directed by David Lowery. ====Voice work==== In 2009, Oldham narrated ''Madam and Little Boy'', a documentary film about atomic weapons, directed by Swedish artist [[:sv:Magnus Bärtås|Magnus Bärtås]]. In 2010, Oldham narrated ''[[Music Makes a City]]'', a documentary about the formation of the [[Louisville Orchestra]], directed by Owsley Brown III and [[Jerome Hiler]].{{Cite news|last=Webster|first=Andy|date=September 17, 2010|title=Louisville, Ky., as a Contemporary Music Hub|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/17/movies/17music.html|access-date=May 19, 2020|issn=0362-4331}} Oldham provided voice work and inspiration for the character "Will" in the video game ''[[Kentucky Route Zero]]'', released in 2013.{{cite web | url=https://www.factmag.com/2016/08/23/kentucky-route-zero-ben-babbitt/ | title=Kentucky Route Zero: How Ben Babbitt scored a Lynchian modern classic | date=August 23, 2016 }} == Personal life == Oldham married the textile artist Elsa Hansen in 2016.{{cite web|title=Watch Bonnie "Prince" Billy Cover Merle Haggard With His Dogs on Morning TV Show – Pitchfork|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/72956-watch-bonnie-prince-billy-cover-merle-haggard-with-his-dogs-on-morning-tv-show/|access-date=August 2, 2017|website=pitchfork.com|date=April 17, 2017 }}{{cite news|last=Pak|first=Minju|date=April 4, 2017|title=Pop Culture Figures – Rendered in Embroidery|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/t-magazine/elsa-hansen-oldham-art-embroidery-cross-stitching.html|access-date=August 2, 2017}} They had a child together in 2018.{{Cite web|title=Episode 40: Will Oldham/Bonnie 'Prince' Billy ClifTones W/ JC Denison podcast|date=December 18, 2018 |url=https://player.fm/series/cliftones-w-jc-denison/episode-40-will-oldhambonnie-prince-billy}} ==Discography== {{main|Will Oldham discography}} === Studio albums === * ''[[There Is No-One What Will Take Care of You]]'' – Palace Brothers (1993)Knott, Alex.
